Not from a statistical standpoint. Our district was gerrymandered to make it less Republican than it would be w/ more natural redistricting.

People falsely assert WPR unconditionally lets president act w/o approval for 60-90 days. No, only for *defensive* action per §2(c), item 3.https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/896018592432619520 …
Consistent with the Constitution, §2(c) limits application of the 60-day provision to item 3, which relates to defensive action.
That would be a *defensive* military action in accordance with item 3.
Yes.
War Powers Res does not allow president to take *offensive* military action without congressional approval. People routinely ignore §2(c).pic.twitter.com/y9u7v3sQUS

Changing our insurance brings the bill under the jurisdiction of additional committees, which violates reconciliation parliamentary rules.
We're the only federal employees who are prohibited from getting insurance from our employer. We purchase from the D.C. ACA exchange.

The House bill did not include Congress and staff bc a reconciliation bill cannot cover our situation. That's why we passed a separate bill.
Sec. Mattis and the White House oppose the amendment. It's the Trump administration that asked us to vote no while they develop a policy.

[5/5] Framers of Constitution were process wonks, who united Americans through process, not policy or power. We need a process-wonk speaker.
[4/5] Process wonks recognize that people of diverse backgrounds will disagree on policy. They seek unity through a fair and open process.
[3/5] Power wonks are not interested in policy or process. They're transactional, caring mostly about how each action enhances their status.
[2/5] Policy wonks believe a few great minds can resolve major policy differences. They view open process as a nuisance that hinders them.
[1/5] There are three types of wonks in Congress: policy wonks, power wonks, and process wonks.

@ByronYork @blakehounshell She violated campaign finance laws, satisfying three-prong unlawful coordination test: https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/631566050543464448 ….
@streiffredstate Main issue isn't polling data; it's unlawful coordinated communication. Akin's campaign paid for ad suggested by McCaskill.
@marceelias We're discussing separate issues. My point is McCaskill was the candidate, and another cmte ran ad at her suggestion. @rickhasen
@imillhiser Ha. I was mostly just surprised that she was so eager to confess to something that appears to be a campaign finance violation.
@imillhiser The law reads "other than that candidate." 11 CFR 109.21
@imillhiser No. The law prohibits expenditure by someone other than the cmte of the candidate (McCaskill), including another candidate cmte.
@imillhiser So? Are you suggesting the law allows coordination with other candidate committees? It doesn't.
@rickhasen This isn't relevant. The alleged unlawful expenditure is not from her side; it's from Akin's side: the Huckabee ad.
@chrisgeidner He mistakenly thinks Akin is the relevant candidate. The violation occurs because McCaskill was a candidate.
@imillhiser There was. McCaskill was the candidate. Violation is that, at her suggestion, someone other than her campaign paid for an ad.
@MEPFuller McCaskill's point in the excerpt is that the ad benefited her. Yes, her actions meet all three prongs of the coordination test.
@MEPFuller A coordinated communication IS an in-kind contribution.
@MEPFuller No. McCaskill was the candidate. Violation is that, at her suggestion, someone other than her campaign paid for an election ad.
@MEPFuller Maybe she thinks it protects her, but "broad generalities" or not, she admits she suggested to Akin's camp that an ad be run.
@MEPFuller McCaskill was the candidate. The ad was paid for and distributed by Akin's campaign at the suggestion of McCaskill.
@MEPFuller Look at the law. Doesn't have to be from PAC. She doesn't need to publicly endorse. She doesn't need to be "materially involved."
@MEPFuller (1) Someone other than McCaskill paid for ad. (2) Ad advocates for a candidate. (3) Ad was distributed at McCaskill's suggestion.
@DavidLKeating Is the law poorly written? Yes. But her actions sure seem to satisfy the three-prong test for coordination.
@DavidLKeating I disagree. She admits that her actions were to benefit her campaign. I'd call it a "misdirection theory" FEC violation.
